description: a(n) = sigma_6(n), the sum of the 6th powers of the divisors of n.
comments: If the canonical factorization of n into prime powers is the product of p^e(p) then sigma_k(n) = Product_p ((p^((e(p)+1)*k))-1)/(p^k-1).Sum_{d|n} 1/d^k is equal to sigma_k(n)/n^k. So sequences A017665-A017712 also give the numerators and denominators of sigma_k(n)/n^k for k = 1..24. The power sums sigma_k(n) are in sequences A000203 (k=1), A001157-A001160 (k=2,3,4,5), A013954-A013972 for k = 6,7,...,24. - Ahmed Fares (ahmedfares(AT)my-deja.com), Apr 05 2001Inverse Mobius transform of A001014. - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 13 2011
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
maple: A013954 := proc(n)        numtheory[sigma][6](n) ;end proc: # _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 13 2011
prog: (Sage) [sigma(n,6)for n in xrange(1,24)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 04 2009(PARI) a(n)=sigma(n,6) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 28, 2011(MAGMA) [DivisorSigma(6,n): n in [1..30]]; // _Bruno Berselli_, Apr 10 2013
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
